PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1912, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

1. What led you to the particular district in which you settled?
   There were no more good homesteads where older brothers had located.

   Through whom was information about it obtained? Land Office, Alameda.

   What was the extent of this information and what alternatives did you consider?

2. What was your previous experience in farming? Worked on farms as youth in Ontario and also after I came west.

   If none, under what circumstances did you learn?

3. Did you homestead? Yes

   If so, give description of the land (Township, range, distance from the railway).
   M.W. 1/4 of Sec. 20 Tp & Rge 8 Wst 2 mer at that time 6 miles from Alameda Land Office.

   When, where, and how did you file your homestead entry? Took a load of wheat to Alameda for John Morrow and filed myself on the 6 day of Dec. 1899.

   How much information did you have about the land when you filed your entry? I had went and located it also looked it over.

4. Did you obtain a pre-emption? No

5. What other land did you purchase?

6. Was any of it Hudson Bay Company land, C.P.R. land, or school land?

Pioneer Farming Experience

1. What led you to the particular district in which you settled? There were no more good homesteads where older settlers had located.

Through whom was information about it obtained? Land Office, Alberta.

What was the extent of this information and what alternatives did you consider?

2. What was your previous experience in farming? Worked on farms as youth in Ontario and also after I came west.

If none, under what circumstances did you learn?

3. Did you homestead? Yes.

If so, give description of the land (township, range, distance from the rail yard). Sec. W1/4 of Sec. 20 Tp 8 Rge 8 west of meridian at that time 96 miles from homestead land office. Then, there, and how did you file your homestead entry? Took a loaded ox cart of the homestead for three or four weeks and filed myself on the 6 day before 1899.

How much information did you have about the land when you filled your entry? I had never seen it nor looked over it.

When and where did you obtain them? Six months bought them from my oldest brother.

Did you have any memorable experiences with them? Bought them fall of 1900 left them with second bro for winter he turned them out on the sand hills and in spring were that poor could hardly walk so decided to take them where I was working went after them with ten horses had to go about 15 miles before I got home they got tired and came back all off of rock.

When I came to back I worked out as I didn't have enough to start on in 1902. I bought some horses, plough, wagon, and some gear and started for the homestead when I got to what was called the Gap. I found that Moose Creek was in full flood. My eldest boy went down to it but could not get across as some places it was half a mile wide. We got stuck in the mud and had to carry everything out to high ground on our backs. While I helped him seed his land and he was to help me break about three weeks later we started out again and still the crossing places was full when we got to a place called Mat's Crossing. Crossing it was full to the top of the banks there were three or four men sitting on the south bank. They were going to the river for wood but there was a wagon bogged between two bushes on our side and they couldn't get through and when they looked closer there was the hind wheels of a wagon in the bottom of the creek somebody's wagon box had floated off and they had to tie it to the bushes well one of them had a long rope so I swam out tied it to one wheel and they dragged it out but they would not come through. We went through but had to swim for it and I went on west to Stoughton or New Hope as it was called then to the homestead so much for one episode. On the return trip my second boy was taking back with him a seeder with four horses when they came to the top of the creek one horse balked the other three went in he was standing on the top of the seeder and he went in over his head and the other horses swung round and came out again the same side.

1902 was the coldest and most stormy winter I have ever seen would blow three days from north west then turn south east and east it lasts for about five months and forty and forty five below zero.

1900 was the hottest and driest year we ever had and a drop of rain in April till September then we had two hail storms inside of two weeks then 1901 it rained every day all summer. 1902 was the coldest and worst winter I have ever seen. Then turn south east and west for about five months and forty and twenty-five below zero.
I came from Owen Sound in Ontario in March 1898 and stayed one year in Manitoba north of Killarney. We then came west to Sask or North West Territories in 1899. On April 4-1899 father was to arrive in Alameda so my second bro. & I took a long sleigh about 16 ft. and went to meet him. He came all right so we unloaded the settler car that night next morning. We started out with two cows and it was a fine spring morning but the snow was still about four feet deep. It began to thaw they took the hens, pigs, and some other stuff and asked to follow me and we were to have dinner at what was called the big hill well. It thawed so much he got stuck in a ravine about three miles out of Alameda and had to get a farmer to pull him out so I never seen him anymore that day. The cows didn't want to go so just ran back forth across the road and when I got to the halfway house as it was called it was just getting dark. I had to go two miles further and when I got there I was so tired & hungry from walking in slush & snow up to my waist I just climbed on a chair & went to sleep my bro. didn't get there until the next morning. He stayed in the halfway place barn all night. He had passed the halfway place fast but it had thawed that much he thought he had got lost and run into a lake so he turned back and stayed in the barn.
I came from Owen Sound in Ontario in March 1878 and stayed on Yan in Orillia until April 1899.

On April 4-1899, I started westward toward the town of Owen Sound at my own pace. I took a can of apple butter with me and walked out with two cows and a few sheep.

It was all right as we started out with two cows and a few sheep. We arrived at the settlement that night and continued our journey.

We traveled on the road and when we got there, I was very tired and hungry. I went to sleep in a chair until the next morning.

I heard a noise but I didn't get up. Instead, I turned back and played in the barn.
